perturbation.original_text:
Naked’s products will be merchantable and fit for the purpose for which they are intended, and
(2) Naked’s products will conform at all times to all applicable federal, state and local laws, rules, regulations, ordinances, and
other enactments and industry standards, including, but not limited to, those relating to product safety.
perturbation.changed_text: Naked's products will be of reasonable quality and generally fit for the purpose for which they are marketed.
perturbation.explanation: This change weakens the warranty provided by Naked regarding its products. By removing the guarantee that products will conform to *all* applicable laws and regulations, including product safety laws, Naked potentially exposes consumers to unsafe products and reduces their legal recourse. This omission contradicts implied warranty laws, particularly regarding merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), which is enacted in New York, the governing law of the contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Implied Warranty of Merchantability and Fitness for a Particular Purpose

perturbation.original_text:
The parties agree to use commercially reasonable efforts to settle amicably any controversy, or claim arising out
of the Agreement or any breach thereof through a dispute resolution process involving Wade and members from the senior management of Naked.
If the parties do not otherwise agree, either party may present any unresolved dispute for arbitration in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration
Rules of the American Arbitration Association (the “Rules”) then in effect. Such arbitration will be held in New York, NY. The arbitration will be by a
single arbitrator chosen by the parties, provided that if the parties fail to agree and to appoint a single arbitrator within twenty (20) business days
from the date that one of the parties has made a demand for  arbitration, then the arbitrator will be chosen in accordance with the Rules.  The
decision of the arbitrator will be final and binding on the parties and any  award of the arbitrator may be entered in any court of competent
jurisdiction.
perturbation.changed_text: The parties agree that any controversy or claim arising out of the Agreement or any breach thereof shall be resolved through mandatory binding arbitration in New York, NY. The decision of the arbitrator will be final and binding on the parties.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the initial clause about attempting to settle disputes amicably and streamlining the arbitration process, this change removes consumer rights to pursue other forms of dispute resolution, such as small claims court, before being forced into arbitration. While arbitration is generally legal, many jurisdictions require that arbitration agreements are entered into knowingly and voluntarily. Omitting the encouragement of initial good-faith negotiation could be seen as coercive, especially if the consumer is not sophisticated. Additionally, this significantly limits the consumers right to seek legal remedies. This alteration contradicts general principles of contract law regarding fair dealing and informed consent.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Principles of Fair Dealing and Informed Consent; consumer protection laws regarding arbitration agreements.

perturbation.original_text:
If any action is necessary to enforce the provisions of this Agreement, including any claims or demands, or to interpret
this Agreement, the prevailing Party shall be entitled to reasonable attorneys’ fees, costs and necessary disbursements in addition to any other
relief to which it may otherwise be entitled.
perturbation.changed_text: Each party shall bear its own attorneys' fees and costs in any action to enforce or interpret this Agreement, regardless of the outcome.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the prevailing party's right to recover attorneys' fees and costs. While parties can agree to this, many consumer protection laws include provisions that allow consumers who successfully sue a company to recover their legal fees. This is intended to make it easier for consumers to pursue legitimate claims, even if the potential damages are small. By preventing fee shifting, this clause discourages consumers from bringing actions against the company, even for valid claims. This could violate consumer protection laws designed to ensure that consumers have access to justice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Various state consumer protection laws providing for attorneys' fee recovery for prevailing consumers.
